title: Data Minimalism vs. Data Maximalism for Rare Disease Drug Repurposing
assumption: More comprehensive multi-modal datasets always improve repurposing predictions
hypothesis: Strategically minimal, high-signal datasets can outperform large, noisy multi-modal approaches for actionable rare disease drug repurposing
evaluationPlan: Controlled comparison using 10 rare diseases, minimal vs maximal datasets, identical model architectures, evaluation on actionability scores and expert agreement
implications: Could unlock repurposing for ultra-rare conditions with extremely limited data and fundamentally change data collection strategies
relatedWork: Multi-modal drug repurposing (Li et al., Yang et al.), data efficiency in ML (Bengio et al.), rare disease informatics
milestones: Month 1: Dataset curation, Month 2: Model training, Month 3: Expert evaluation
successCriteria: >15% improvement in expert actionability ratings, <50% of maximal dataset size, maintained predictive performance
notes: Core experiment testing fundamental data assumption

title: Actionability-First vs. Accuracy-First Model Design
assumption: Predictive accuracy is the primary success metric for AI systems
hypothesis: Models optimized for clinical actionability (interpretability, uncertainty quantification) produce better real-world outcomes than accuracy-optimized models
evaluationPlan: Blinded clinician evaluation comparing accuracy-optimized vs actionability-optimized models on standardized clinical decision scenarios
implications: Could bridge the gap between AI predictions and clinical implementation by changing fundamental evaluation metrics
relatedWork: Interpretable ML (Ribeiro et al.), clinical decision support systems, uncertainty quantification in healthcare AI
milestones: Month 2: Model development, Month 3: Scenario creation, Month 4: Clinician evaluation
successCriteria: >20% higher implementation likelihood, >25% improvement in clinician confidence scores
notes: Tests core assumption about evaluation metrics in clinical AI

title: Cross-Disease Transfer Learning Validation
assumption: Each rare disease requires disease-specific computational approaches
hypothesis: Shared mechanistic patterns across rare diseases can be leveraged through transfer learning to outperform disease-specific models
evaluationPlan: Meta-learning across 50+ rare diseases, comparison against disease-specific baselines, generalization testing on novel diseases
implications: Could enable repurposing for diseases with insufficient individual datasets and reveal universal therapeutic mechanisms
relatedWork: Meta-learning (Finn et al.), transfer learning in biomedicine, rare disease mechanisms
milestones: Month 4: Disease clustering, Month 5: Meta-model training, Month 6: Generalization testing
successCriteria: >30% improvement for ultra-rare diseases, successful generalization to 5+ novel diseases

title: Parallel vs. Sequential Validation Strategies
assumption: Drug validation must follow linear preclinical â†’ clinical stages
hypothesis: Parallel validation using real-world evidence can accelerate repurposing timelines without compromising safety
evaluationPlan: Simulation study comparing parallel vs sequential validation pathways for 20 candidate drug-disease pairs, safety outcome analysis
implications: Could dramatically reduce time-to-treatment for rare disease patients while maintaining safety standards
relatedWork: Real-world evidence studies, drug repurposing validation, regulatory science
milestones: Month 6: Protocol design, Month 7: Simulation modeling, Month 8: Safety analysis
successCriteria: >40% timeline reduction, equivalent safety signal detection, maintained regulatory acceptance
notes: Tests fundamental assumption about validation sequencing

title: Human-AI Collaborative Intelligence vs. Full Automation
assumption: AI should minimize human bias and replace expert judgment
hypothesis: Hybrid human-AI systems that amplify clinical expertise outperform fully automated approaches for complex repurposing decisions
evaluationPlan: Comparative study with rare disease clinicians using collaborative interface vs automated predictions on complex cases
implications: Could leverage irreplaceable rare disease expertise while scaling discovery capabilities
relatedWork: Human-AI collaboration (Bansal et al.), clinical decision making, expert systems
milestones: Month 6: Interface development, Month 8: Clinician studies, Month 10: Analysis
successCriteria: >25% improvement in complex case handling, >3x novel insight generation, >90% expert satisfaction
notes: Tests core assumption about AI vs human expertise

title: Integrated System Performance Validation
assumption: Individual improvements cannot be combined effectively
hypothesis: Integrated system incorporating all validated assumption flips will show synergistic benefits
evaluationPlan: Build integrated system combining validated approaches, comprehensive comparison against state-of-the-art baselines
implications: Demonstrates feasibility of paradigm shift in AI drug repurposing
relatedWork: Systems integration studies, clinical AI implementation
milestones: Month 9: System integration, Month 11: Validation studies, Month 13: Performance analysis
successCriteria: >50% improvement in overall clinical actionability, maintained prediction quality
notes: Validates combined benefit of all assumption flips
